phases.name: Inventory
phases.description: Identify cryptographic assets and dependencies (internal and external).

controls.question: Have all non-quantum-safe cryptographic assets been identified?
evidence: Cryptographic Asset Inventory (export/CMDB/CSV) including: system/app, crypto library/module, algorithm, key sizes, certificates/PKI usage, location, owner.
Documented method used for discovery (manual review, scanning, SBOM, code search, config audit).
Last update date + responsible role.

actions.yes: Maintain an up-to-date cryptographic asset inventory.
actions.partial: Complete the inventory by including legacy systems and overlooked repositories.
actions.no: Initiate an immediate cryptographic asset census to establish a baseline.

controls.question: Have all cryptographically protected assets been identified and assessed?
evidence: List of data/assets protected by cryptography (data at rest/in transit/signatures), mapped to confidentiality needs and retention horizon.
Classification or criticality rating for each protected asset (business impact).
Link/mapping from protected assets to crypto mechanisms used (ties to inventory).

actions.yes: Perform periodic reassessments of cryptographically protected assets.
actions.partial: Integrate missing protected assets and update the assessment scope
actions.no: Launch a structured assessment to identify where cryptography is used and why.

controls.question: Have internal dependencies involving cryptography been mapped?
evidence: Architecture/data-flow diagrams showing where cryptography is used across internal systems (APIs, TLS termination points, message queues, databases, HSM/KMS).
Dependency map between applications/services and crypto components (libraries, protocols, PKI services).
Identification of 'crypto choke points' (shared services) and legacy constraints.

actions.yes: Maintain an updated dependency map across internal systems.
actions.partial: Extend mapping to include supporting and ancillary systems.
actions.no: Initiate internal dependency mapping to identify critical data flows and trust boundaries.

controls.question: Have external dependencies and suppliers relying on cryptography been identified?
evidence: Supplier/third-party inventory including SaaS, cloud, MSP, PKI providers, payment/ID providers, and critical outsourced services.
For each supplier: crypto touchpoints (TLS, VPN, signing, storage encryption), and where keys/certs are managed.
Evidence of supplier PQC posture request/questionnaire or documented outreach.

actions.yes: Enforce cryptographic requirements through supplier contracts.
actions.partial: Complete and validate the supplier inventory, including relevant subcontractors.
actions.no: Initiate supplier assessment focusing on cryptographic usage and shared services.

phases.name: Risk Assessment
phases.description: Assess quantum vulnerability, threats, impacts, and migration effort to prioritize action.

controls.question: Has the quantum vulnerability of cryptographic assets been assessed?
evidence: Documented assessment of which crypto assets are vulnerable to Shor/Grover class attacks (e.g., RSA/ECC exposure).
Assumptions on data lifetime (how long confidentiality must hold) and HNDL relevance.
Risk model notes (method used, scope, date, owners).

actions.yes: Maintain an up-to-date quantum risk model and documented assumptions.
actions.partial: Integrate missing scenarios (e.g., harvest-now-decrypt-later) into the assessment.
actions.no: Initiate a quantum vulnerability assessment to prioritize exposed assets.

controls.question: Have relevant quantum-related threat scenarios been identified and analysed?
evidence: Threat scenarios list (e.g., HNDL, compromise of PKI, code-signing, VPN/TLS interception, long-term archives).
Impact analysis per scenario (CIA + operational impact), linked to critical assets/processes.
Input sources: CTI reports, incident history, sector threat profile.

actions.yes: Maintain an impact matrix aligned with business and technological changes
actions.partial: Extend the analysis to uncovered assets or business processes.
actions.no: Perform a threat and impact analysis to estimate potential consequences.

controls.question: Has the effort required for PQC migration been estimated?
evidence: Effort estimate document (people-days/cost) covering: discovery, design, testing, deployment, rollback/contingency.
Dependency constraints list (vendors, legacy systems, protocol limitations, hardware/HSM constraints).
Skills/tooling gap assessment (training needs, external support).

actions.yes: Maintain updated effort estimates within the PQC roadmap.
actions.partial: Integrate missing cost components (skills, testing, vendor constraints).
actions.no: Perform an effort analysis to estimate migration workload and dependencies.

controls.question: Has PQC-related risk been calculated and prioritized?
evidence: Risk register entries specific to PQC (risk statement, likelihood, impact, current controls).
Prioritization criteria (asset criticality, data lifetime, exposure, supplier dependency, feasibility).
Resulting ranked list of assets/systems for migration sequencing.

actions.yes: Maintain a risk register reflecting PQC exposure and business priorities.
actions.partial: Complete risk prioritization by aligning scores with asset criticality.
actions.no: Execute risk calculation to define migration order and urgency.

phases.name: Compliance
phases.description: Assess compliance with general and sector-specific requirements; ensure alignment with standards and guidance.

controls.question: Has compliance with general regulatory and standard requirements been assessed?
owner: Cyber Legal, Policy and Compliance Officer
evidence: Compliance mapping document (requirements → existing controls → gaps) for general obligations.
Audit evidence pack (policies, procedures, logs, prior audit reports) supporting compliance claims.
Named owner and review cadence.

actions.yes: Maintain periodic compliance audits and supporting evidence.
actions.partial: Extend compliance assessments to uncovered departments, assets, or processes.
actions.no: Perform a compliance gap analysis to identify applicable requirements and remediation actions.

controls.question: Has compliance with sector-specific regulatory requirements been assessed?
owner: Cyber Legal, Policy and Compliance Officer
evidence: Sector-specific obligations list (applicable regulation/authority requirements) and applicability rationale.
Gap analysis and remediation plan tailored to sector requirements (including reporting/notification duties).
Evidence of governance involvement (minutes, approvals, compliance sign-off).

actions.yes: Perform regular reviews against applicable sector-specific regulations and obligations.
actions.partial: Complete the sector-specific gap analysis by mapping existing controls to regulatory requirements.
actions.no: Initiate a sector-specific regulatory assessment to identify obligations and reporting expectations.

controls.question: Is alignment with PQC-related standards and guidance ensured?
evidence: List of adopted/monitored standards and guidance (e.g., NIST PQC, ETSI, ENISA, national guidance), with review date.
Internal position statement: which PQC approaches are allowed (hybrid, crypto-agility, algorithm choices) and why.
Traceability from guidance → roadmap decisions (link to PLAN-01).

actions.yes: Maintain alignment with applicable PQC-related standards and strategic guidance.
actions.partial: Integrate newly issued standards, guidance, and recommendations into internal planning.
actions.no: Initiate a standards alignment activity to identify relevant PQC frameworks and guidance.

phases.name: Planning
phases.description: Define the roadmap and integrate policies, supplier management, budget, and training.

controls.question: Has a post-quantum cryptography roadmap been defined?
evidence: Formal PQC roadmap document with milestones, timelines, dependencies, owners, and success criteria.
Prioritized migration sequence linked to risk results (RA-04) and inventory scope (INV-*).
Plan includes pilot/testing, rollout, fallback/rollback strategy, and communications.

actions.yes: Maintain and periodically update the PQC roadmap as scope, risks, and standards evolve.
actions.partial: Integrate missing milestones, dependencies, or pilot activities into the existing roadmap
actions.no: Define a PQC roadmap outlining phases, priorities, timelines, and success criteria.

controls.question: Have internal policies and procedures been updated to address PQC?
owner: Cyber Legal, Policy and Compliance Officer
evidence: Updated crypto policy/procedure documents including PQC strategy, crypto-agility requirements, exception handling.
Change control / approval evidence (policy approval record, version history).
Internal communication/training note that policies were disseminated.

actions.yes: Maintain governance over updated cryptographic policies and procedures addressing PQC.
actions.partial: Extend existing policies to include PQC requirements, crypto agility, and exception handling.
actions.no: Update internal policies and procedures to formally address PQC strategy and controls.

controls.question: Has supplier management been integrated into the PQC strategy?
evidence: Supplier contract clauses / procurement requirements addressing cryptography and PQC readiness (or roadmap commitments).
Supplier questionnaire results or attestations on PQC support and crypto-agility.
Escalation plan for non-compliant suppliers (mitigation/alternative suppliers).

actions.yes: Maintain PQC-related requirements and cryptographic clauses within supplier management processes.
actions.partial: Extend PQC requirements to additional suppliers, subcontractors, and critical services.
actions.no: Initiate supplier management activities focused on PQC readiness and cryptographic dependencies.

controls.question: Have financial resources for PQC migration been planned and approved?
evidence: Budget plan covering tooling, vendor upgrades, testing, training, external consulting, and operational overhead.
Approval evidence (budget sign-off, procurement request, funding allocation).
Cost tracking mechanism aligned to roadmap milestones.

actions.yes: Maintain an approved PQC budget aligned with the defined roadmap and priorities.
actions.partial: Integrate missing cost components such as skills, tooling, testing, and vendor support.
actions.no: Define the required PQC budget and obtain formal financial approval.

controls.question: Have training and awareness activities been planned?
evidence: Training plan (audience, modules, schedule) covering PQC basics, crypto-agility, migration impacts, roles/responsibilities.
Attendance records or LMS exports for completed trainings.
Awareness materials distributed (slides, internal comms, FAQs).

actions.yes: Maintain a structured training and awareness program addressing PQC risks and responsibilities.
actions.partial: Extend training activities to additional technical, security, and procurement roles
actions.no: Launch baseline training and awareness initiatives on post-quantum cryptography.

phases.name: Monitoring
phases.description: Continuously monitor standards/regulations, vulnerabilities, supplier readiness, and roadmap progress.

controls.question: Is regulatory and standards evolution related to PQC continuously monitored?
owner: Cyber Legal, Policy and Compliance Officer
evidence: Documented monitoring process (sources, cadence, ownership) for PQC-related regulations/standards.
Change log capturing relevant updates and resulting internal actions.
Evidence of periodic review meetings or reports.

actions.yes: Maintain continuous monitoring of PQC-related regulations, standards, and guidance.
actions.partial: Integrate newly issued regulatory updates and standards into periodic reviews.
actions.no: Establish a formal process to monitor regulatory and standards evolution related to PQC.

controls.question: Are cryptographic vulnerabilities continuously monitored?
evidence: Vulnerability monitoring setup (feeds, scanners, CVE tracking) including crypto libraries and dependencies.
SOC/CTI procedures for triage, patching, and exception handling.
Sample ticket(s)/report(s) showing detection → remediation workflow.

actions.yes: Maintain continuous monitoring of cryptographic and PQC-related vulnerabilities.
actions.partial: Extend vulnerability monitoring to additional cryptographic libraries, platforms, and vendors.
actions.no: Integrate cryptographic vulnerability monitoring into SOC and threat intelligence processes.

controls.question: Are external dependencies and suppliers periodically audited for PQC readiness?
evidence: Audit plan and audit reports for suppliers/third parties focused on crypto/PQC readiness.
Supplier evidence (attestations, roadmap statements, test results, compliance reports).
Corrective action tracking for audit findings.

actions.yes: Maintain periodic audits of suppliers and external dependencies focusing on PQC readiness.
actions.partial: Extend audit scope to include additional suppliers, subcontractors, or shared services.
actions.no: Conduct an initial audit of external dependencies and suppliers for PQC readiness.

controls.question: Is progress of the PQC roadmap tracked and reported?
evidence: KPIs/dashboard or status reports showing roadmap progress (milestones completed, blockers, risks).
Governance reporting evidence (steering committee minutes, periodic updates).
Issue/risk log linked to roadmap and mitigation actions.

actions.yes: Maintain KPIs and dashboards to track PQC roadmap progress and implementation status.
actions.partial: Extend progress tracking to include suppliers, legacy systems, and validation milestones.
actions.no: Establish formal tracking and reporting mechanisms for PQC roadmap progress.
